full_original_html:
Two blocks m1 & m2 are kept on a smooth horizontal table as shown in figure. A force F is applied on mass m1 at an angle θ. Normal reaction between ground and m1 is N1 ground & m2 is N2 & between two blocks is N3. Coefficient of friction between blocks is m and mass m1 = m2. Then




If N1 = 0 and μ = 1; F is minimum at θ = tan–1(2) for no relative motion between two blocks

If μ = 0 and N1 = 0 then m2 will be static
There is no possible value of F for which N2 is zero, if μ ≠ 0
For N1 = 0, N3 can never be zero

(ii) a' = (αβ) a
(iii) F' = [1/αβ] F

Length standards of the two systems are related by L' = (α3/β3) L
Mass standards of the two systems are related by : M' = (1 / α2β2) M
Time standards of the two systems are related by T' = (α/β2) T
Momentum standards of the two systems are related by p' = (1/β3) p

Figure shows a fixed wedge with a groove in it. A small block lies inside groove just filling it.



If groove is smooth the acceleration of block along groove is g sinθ sin α

If friction acts from side walls only the minimum coefficient of friction required to hold block stationary is tan α

If friction acts on base of block only the minimum coefficient of friction required to hold block stationary is µ = tan θ.

If groove is smooth the acceleration of block along groove is g sinθ cos α.

full_original_html:
Two blocks m1 & m2 are kept on a smooth horizontal table as shown in figure. A force F is applied on mass m1 at an angle θ. Normal reaction between ground and m1 is N1 ground & m2 is N2 & between two blocks is N3. Coefficient of friction between blocks is m and mass m1 = m2. Then




If N1 = 0 and μ = 1; F is minimum at θ = tan–1(2) for no relative motion between two blocks

If μ = 0 and N1 = 0 then m2 will be static
There is no possible value of F for which N2 is zero, if μ ≠ 0
For N1 = 0, N3 can never be zero

The surface of the inner sphere is kept at a temperature of T1 = 320 K, and that of the outer sphere at a temperature of T2 = 300 K. In these conditions, a steady  heat flux of dQ/dt = 2.00 kW flows from the inner sphere to the outer one. Considering the thermal conductivity coefficient K for the substance in the gap to be independent of the temperature :



the value of K= 13.3 W/(m.K);
the value of K= 23.3 W/(m.K);
the temperature T(r) in the gap as a function of the distance r from the centre of the spheres. T = 200 + 12/r. (T is in K, and r is in m).
the temperature T(r) in the gap as a function of the distance r from the centre of the spheres. T = 300 + 6/r. (T is in K, and r is in m).

full_original_html:
Two boats were going in opposite direction one along down stream and the other one along upstream with different velocities. When one overtook the other a plastic ball was dropped from one of the boats. Some time later both boats turned back simultaneously & went at the same speeds as before (relative to the water) towards the spot where the ball had been dropped. Which boat will reach the ball first?


the boat which has greater velocity (relative to water)
the boat which has lesser velocity (relative to water)
both will reach the ball simultaneously
cannot be decided unless we know the actual values of the velocities and the time after which they turned around.

full_original_html:
Figure shows the circuit diagram of a potentiometer apparatus. P is the point, where jockey would touch potentiometer. (Length of potentiometer wire = 10 m, resistance of potentiometer wire = 450 Ω and 10V battery is ideal.)



Potential gradient of potentiometer wire at null deflection would be 0.9 V/m.

For any location of P, we can not have null deflection point.

For a particular point P, current at point 1 can be made zero, but never at point 2.

For P coinciding with B current at point 1 would be in vertically upwards direction.
